review_title: Good work/life balance, low salary, concerning trajectory
pros: HP Boise had great employee groups(I loved participating in the Young Employees Network and Volleyball leagues). The work/life balance is generally good as you'll find the parking lots mostly empty by 6. The overall engineering culture is still quite good, especially if you get on a team working on a new exciting project.
cons:
Unfortunately, there are quite a few reasons why I wouldn't recommend pursuing a job at HP right now.

There have been significant layoffs with various teams in the past few years. The company claims it's invested in Boise yet the headcount has been on a steady march downward. The high-end firmware, low-end firmware, and cloud(Roam) engineering teams have been gutted at various points, with work moving to Vancouver, India("the Hub"), or Korea(ex-Samsung). This has also led to significant attrition of top talent. Of my entire "generation"(5-10 years), almost everyone I know has left.

Simply put, you won't get the best salary at HP. Comparing salary notes with former coworkers, you can expect a 25-30% better salary with other companies in the area(Intuit, Cradlepoint, Kount, Micron, etc). 

The overall direction of the company is perpetually depressing. Let's face it -- printing is not a growing business nor will it be in the future. The trend is that every quarter the financials are either flat or declining. HP has already saturated the printer market. If you're not getting a great salary, why work somewhere that's on the decline?

job_title: Inside Sales Account Manager in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Diversity, inclusion, social office in Rio Rancho, team oriented employees to help you. There aren't many helicopter managers, allowing for freedom to work how you want to work. Relatively relaxed environment; lots of time to be social in between email tasks.
cons: Trainings are out dated and need updating to educate and correctly onboard. The gender wage gap is 100% real (same degree, experience, job title results in a difference in $10k in salary gap between men and women). Compensation for commission is a mess; at times, pay out for sales commissions don't hit your account for 3 to 6 months after sale is completed. When management asks sales how to improve strategies/tools/processes, the common response to any suggestion outside of what they want to hear is "there's nothing we can do ," all the way up to director level. This site and the teams within just float, lacking any initiative to propel themselves forward, design anything new, etc. Toxic work environment, full of gossip and teenager mentalities; your manager won't watch the clock but your peers will on their behalf. The environment is a little better in a WFH scenario. Half of the W2s received from this company have been wrong and needed to be updated before I could file for taxes.

job_title: Software Developer I in Corvallis, OR
pros:
* Tend to have a pretty strong focus on work/life balance. Unlimited sick leave, no questions asked about leaving for appointments, things like that. 
* Co-workers are generally pretty nice. People seem to like the work they're doing. 
* Any equipments needs you have are met pretty readily. Software is slightly harder to get a hold of--but can still be done. 
* While pay is not the best, pretty generous bonuses. 
* HP is my first place, but I get the vibe speaking to others that the meeting load is pretty light here. Tend to prioritize people having the time to do their work rather than having them sit in long, pointless meetings.
cons:
* Managers tend to set unrealistic deadlines. They don't expect people to work overtime to meet these deadlines, at least not that I see--but it does lead to a lot of unnecessary shifting and shuffling of schedules. 
* It definitely feels like there's a strong tilt towards male-identifying employees. Would be nice to see more gender diversity in the workplace.

Upper management only cares about the stock prices. This means that HP will do everything possible to show a profit every quarter. R&D is the most flexible budget so when a profit isn't being shown projects will lose funding and employees will be laid off.
HP does not like taking risks. They often have the ideas and resources to be the first to invent something but they never go for it unless there is already an established market to try to shove in.

pros: Best Place to Work in 2019 The Hewlett-Packard Company, commonly shortened to Hewlett-Packard (/ˈhjuːlɪt ˈpækərd/ HEW-lit PAK-ərd) or HP, was an American multinational information technology company headquartered in Palo Alto, California, that developed and provided a wide variety of hardware components, as well as software and related services to consumers, small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs) and large enterprises, including customers in the government, health and education sectors. The company was founded in a one-car garage in Palo Alto, California by Bill Hewlett and David Packard in 1939, and initially produced a line of electronic test and measurement equipment. The HP Garage at 367 Addison Avenue is now designated an official California Historical Landmark, and is marked with a plaque calling it the "Birthplace of 'Silicon Valley'".

cons: Since engineers run the show, well-executed projects that are commercial flops are common. On top of this, printing is becoming more and more untenable as a place to compete. It's already mostly a commodity, but with resellers eating into the inky life-blood there are shrinking pains aplenty at HP. Pay is medium to low, but if you live in boring Vancouver, one can avoid income taxes so there's that.

pros: People are great. I liked every team I was on and everybody I worked with.
cons:
It seems disorganized, which is rather ironic when they seem to do a reorg every 6 months.

They also seem uncommitted to change -- meaning that they want to try something new, and they'll pay lip service to it and devote resources to it, until the next reorg where they get cold feet and either change this new idea back into the equivalent of New Coke or skip it entirely like windows 9. Which is understandable considering everything about hp, but it would be nice if they just stopped the lip service part of this cycle.

Also, there seems to be frequent layoffs -- not quite every six months, but it certainly seemed like it.
